meanings.definition: To remove or destroy the roots of (something)
meanings.sent1: The gardener had to unroot the stubborn weed from the flower bed.
meanings.sent2: It is important to unroot invasive plants to protect the garden.
meanings.sent3: The determined squirrel tried to unroot the buried acorn but couldn't.
meanings.sent4: Her words seemed to unroot his confidence, leaving him unsure.
meanings.sent5: The storm's strong winds threatened to unroot the old tree from the ground.

meanings.sent1: The team worked together to unroot the corruption in the system.
meanings.sent2: It took years to unroot the deeply ingrained traditions.
meanings.sent3: The detective was determined to unroot the criminal organization.
meanings.sent4: The new medicine promised to unroot the disease plaguing the town.
meanings.sent5: Their efforts to unroot poverty in the community were finally paying off.

meanings.definition: To dislodge or uproot from a place or position
meanings.sent1: The strong wind threatened to unroot the tent from the ground.
meanings.sent2: The construction crew had to unroot the old foundation before building.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy managed to unroot the flowerpot from the shelf.
meanings.sent4: The earthquake's force could unroot even the sturdiest of structures.
meanings.sent5: The floodwaters had the power to unroot trees along the riverbank.
